argumentText:
ARGUMENT

| Step | Hyp | Ref | Expression |
|---|---|---|---|

| 1 |  | #P_sb5 | |- ( [ z / x ] ph <-> E. x ( x = z /\ ph ) ) |
| 2 | 1 | #P_sbbii | |- ( [ y / z ] [ z / x ] ph <-> [ y / z ] E. x ( x = z /\ ph ) ) |
| 3 |  | #P_ax-17 | |- ( ph -> A. z ph ) |
| 4 | 3 | #P_sbco2v | |- ( [ y / z ] [ z / x ] ph <-> [ y / x ] ph ) |
| 5 |  | #P_sb5 | |- ( [ y / z ] E. x ( x = z /\ ph ) <-> E. z ( z = y /\ E. x ( x = z /\ ph ) ) ) |
| 6 | 2, 4, 5 | #P_3bitr3i | |- ( [ y / x ] ph <-> E. z ( z = y /\ E. x ( x = z /\ ph ) ) ) |
\
 An alternate definition of proper substitution ~ df-sb .  By introducing a dummy variable ` z ` in the definiens, we are able to eliminate any distinct variable restrictions among the variables ` x ` , ` y ` , and ` ph ` of the definiendum.  No distinct variable conflicts arise because ` z ` effectively insulates ` x ` from ` y ` .  To achieve this, we use a chain of two substitutions in the form of ~ sb5 , first ` z ` for ` x ` then ` y ` for ` z ` .  Compare Definition 2.1'' of [Quine] p. 17.  Theorem ~ sb7f provides a version where ` ph ` and ` z ` don't have to be distinct.  (Contributed by NM, 28-Jan-2004.)
